reviewText:
Not quite as user-friendly as Turbo Tax, but I had no problem using it.
I would have used the Federal refund gift card + 10% but they did not offer it on Amazon (like Turbo Tax does) so I passed on that.
Still, the cost is reasonable and it seems to work well. Very likely I will use H&R Block tax software again next tax year.

I've used Quicken versions 2003, 2006, 2008 and now 2011. After "upgrading" from 2008 Deluxe I immediately noticed the following:

-- The program opens more slowly and is much slower moving between screens
-- Transactions download from my bank (Chase) very slowly (I use web connect)
-- You can no longer click <enter> to accept downloaded transactions when a match is found in the register
-- There is no more Reconcile button at the top of my register; it's under a new Account Actions button (annoying)

That's just what I've noticed in the 2 weeks I've been using it. On the plus side, it appears to have converted all my 2008 Deluxe data without a hitch. I upgraded because I was forced to by Intuit's 3 year software expiration policy. I have found nothing in version 2011 that wasn't already in 2008, at least for my own needs.

At this point I can only recommend this software if you're an existing Quicken user, are being forced to upgrade, and would rather not re-learn a whole new program. If you're switching from something else, such as Money, you should take the time to research better (sometimes free!) alternatives before putting money down on this. Intuit doesn't make any actual improvements to Quicken every year - it simply refreshes the look of the interface, moves previously well-placed buttons in new locations, and charges you $60.00 for the privilege.
No product support do not buy..
It work

Overall a robust and reliable product, but:

Expect to spend another couple hundred dollars a year for support, either on a plan or at ~$50 per call.

Doesn't run on Linux. That's a huge downfall for a business product. If you want the stability of running on a dedicated Windows server instead of a user machine, it'll cost you an additional user license for the server in addition to each user.

I was a MS Money 07 user until I switched to a Mac desktop and lost my installation key to re-install MS Money on my virtual machine.  I must admit that I LOVED MS Money  and am disappointed that they are discontinuing to make the product. Very robust product with a ton of functionality.

While I've only been using it for 5 days, Quicken Essentials for Mac is not quite as terrible as the other reviewers are making it out to be but there is absolutely room for improvement.  I would say my biggest complaint is lack of flexibility.  You have very VERY little control over the way your data is displayed.  For instance, in the Overview screen, it shows my top 5 expenses for the month, however I have 3 fixed expense categories (rent, loans, and mutual funds) that will always be the top 3.  I'd rather it display the top 7 or maybe the top 5, but allow me to exclude some categories from being displayed.  It would be great if you could customize the Overview screen to display information that would actually be helpful based on your spending/saving goals.  For instance, I'd love for it to show me changes in my mutual funds/stocks, or if I'm spending more than last month on clothes/food/whatever...however it does not.

I heard someone say it "doesn't do stocks" however I have stocks and didn't have any problem.  It doesn't automatically update them... I have to go to the web site and download the qfx file but I don't really mind this.  I also have an IRA and a 401k that it auto-syncs.

On the positive side, while the software does very little, what it does do it does decently. There are some nice (though, as aforementioned, uncustomizeable) pie charts, you can create your own categories and tags, and scheduling future transactions went fairly smoothly.

Thumbs Down:
* No flexibility to display data
* Just update automatically or when I open the program!! Instead I have to ask it to update the accounts and go through an irritating dialog.  At least provide a setting for this!
* Very very limited settings and customizability.  Doesn't conform to users needs.  Settings are basically worthless.
* Could use some more stock/mutual fund analysis tools. Nothing fancy - just show me time-over-time increases, my poor/good performers...etc.  Also, you can't really edit any of the mutual fund/stock info.  For instance, one of my accounts doesn't display symbols.  I'd like to type in the symbols myself, however there is no way to do that.

Unsure:
* Budgeting tool - doesn't seem robust enough, however after I get a few more months data in there it might be helpful.
* Matching - I haven't really used this functionality yet.
* For future transactions I had to enter an amount, however there are times I don't really know the amount.  For instance, my heating bill is rarely the exact same each month.  Not sure if QE for Mac is going to pick up on this or not.

Thumbs Up:
* Set up was fairly simple for me.  I was not importing any data (my MS Money file couldn't be imported because I needed the MS Money software operating to export it into a readable fashion)
* Found all of my financial institutions
* Nice little graphics and intuitive layout
* takes advantage of Macs finder/search tool
* can be saved to mobile me....nice.  I haven't actually tried doing this yet or what the real advantage would be.

At this point I'm going to stick with this product because it is better than nothing and I haven't found another tool out there.  Someone recommended YNAB, however after exploring their site it doesn't do mutual fund/stock tracking.  If anyone else knows of a good product, write me a comment!  Thanks.

I support residential and business clients and on one particular business client job, I had the task of salvaging a crashed IDE hard disk and hopefully 7 years worth of business and personal data. In my tool kit, I had a SATA hard disk, a USB SATA hard disk dock, and an Acronis CD which is bootable on the off chance Windows won't boot up. On this job I ran a separate utility to move data to good locations of the hard disk and mark of the bad sectors/blocks. Once this completed, I attempted to boot into Windows XP and was successful. Now it was time for Acronis. I restarted the PC but booted into Acronis instead of Windows and chose the option to clone the drive to the good external SATA hard disk I had. It did this without any errors. I then verified with the client that all their data was now on the cloned SATA drive and then I simply cloned the SATA drive back onto a replacement IDE hard disk I had purchased for Their PC. End result: Other than having to replace a Windows XP .dll file and reinstalling their wireless mouse software, all their data and Windows XP was intact and they were once again able to work as if the hard disk hadn't crashed. I was a hero to them and it felt good. Now, for non techs, it is one thing to back up data to an external hard disk or on a cloud server but in the event of a hard disk crash, having to reinstall Windows (usually not an option if it came on your PC) and all your applications takes up a lot more time than I would guess you have. That is where Acronis shines as a backup program. You do one full backup of your entire system (includes data)and then use Acronis' backup scheduler to automatically do weekly or even daily incremental backups that back up only the changes that occurred since the initial full backup. Once it is set up, all you have to do is make sure your external backup hard disk is turned on the day and time your backup is scheduled for. In the event your hard disk crashes beyond repair, you have the hard disk replaced, boot up with the Acronis CD and restore from your backup, everything! Operating system, data, Outlook settings, pictures, music, videos, everything that was there before the crash. Bottom line: I've used this software for 3 years, now and I swear by it.

Update: I have since installed Acronis True Image 2011 version on my PC and a new option is available in this version and the one prior to it called "Nonstop Backup". What this does is do an initial full backup and then running in the background, it frequently checks for changes and then records only those changes as it detects them. This means, if you have a critical problem with Windows or a hard disk crash in the evening and you get a replacement internal hard disk, you can recover your Windows, programs and data from that morning's backup file. Sweet!

If you have every upgraded software before, you are well aware that there is a learning curve associated with the new software.  Even if there are some neat new features, it can take some time finding how things are done differently.

I have been using Word 2003 and Excel 2003 for over 10 years and I am very comfortable with how it works.  I did not see anything wrong with those versions.  The newer version included in Office 365 (which seems to be the 2007 versions) have a totally different look and feel. I am having trouble seeing any real benefits to the upgrade.  Maybe with time, I will become accustomed to the newer version and hopefully will find some benefits. But right now, all I am doing is spending a lot of time learning the new layout/functions.

The one huge benefit I can see is that you can now store your files in the cloud.  Microsoft offers up to 20GB of online storage included with the subscription price.
This allows you to be able to access your files from any location where you have Internet access.

There are a couple of other new features that may be beneficial  OneNote and Outlook.  Personally I do not use Outlook so that is of no value to me.  I am just exploring OneNote but is seems like it has some good features that may prove helpful.

I am not a big fan of subscription software.  I think it is possible to pay for it 2 or 3 times over by buying it as a subscription.

As a lot of people have observed, the Personal version only allows an installation on one desktop and one laptop.  If you are going to purchase, the Home version seems to be a better deal.

I am still getting used to the new version and often when in a hurry and need to get something done will work in my 2003 versions.  Those are still fully functional and work fine with no interference from Office 365 (this review was written in Word 2003).

I got Pocket Money back in 2001 shortly after getting my first Palm pilot. This program alone justifies my need to have a Palm PDA. I have used it for keeping track of my money transactions for since then. I can have several accounts stored in the program, and run transfers between them. The very first transaction is dated July 24, 2001 and it still appears on record.

It's even helpful for budgeting. When I deposit money, I get on this program and start deducting off future bills and upcoming expenses. The convenient part is I can mark these accounts as "not cleared" which means I can see two different totals, one being the actual total and then the "Cleared Totals" only.

Repeated transactions can be done automatically as well. Just set up a transaction and then tell it how often that transaction will occur.

You can password protect entry into the Pocket Money program. Also, notes can be added to transactions (so you can store receipt numbers or other info). You can set limit alerts on particular account. If you pass that limit, the program displays a message.

You can also set categories for particular transactions.  For instance, if I buy something for my business, I just mark it under the category `business (or anything you want).  Then, when Tax time rolls around, I can view just the transactions under the business category.  Makes it easier to remember what needs to be deducted.

I've had this program follow me through my Palm M100, a Handspring Prism, yet another Handspring Prism (first one met an unfortunate demise), and finally my Treo 650. Its especially convenient that Hot-sync backs up the database. I've had a few harsh crashed and I've been able to get my database back every time (minus un-synced actions).

When I was considering getting a smart phone, the ability to load a good working money management program was a priority, so it made getting the Treo a good deal.

While I do really like this program, there are some quirks I've noticed over the years.

1. I have one automatic transaction that I can't seem to stop. I no longer need the program to stop repeating this particular transaction but for some reason it won't stop. In the end, every 15th of a month I have to delete that action manually.

2. Despite what the box and instructions said I never seemed to manage importing/exporting into Quicken or Microsoft Money. I'm using Version 2 so maybe the Version 3 they are selling works better. I was a little upset about this at first, but I think I like it better as a Stand-Alone. I use Microsoft Money for verifying my accounts and Pocket Money for in the field record keeping. Besides, every time you sync your device IT WILL BACKUP the Pocket Money database, which is good enough for me.

3. Some higher functions, like "rolling up transactions" crash the device. This has happened every time I try to do those functions and on every device I have had. I don't know what the deal is, but I haven't needed those functions so I guess its not important.

I'm giving a review based on Version 2.0 of Pocket Money and they're selling Version 3.1.2 now. I'm sure there might be some changes and improvements, but based on the screenshots from Handmark's website, it looks very similar to my version. Just a few added bells and whistles. I'm considering moving to the newer version, and probably starting fresh (four years of records can a database really large.)

Even with those quirks, I still give this program 5stars. I can't believe how simple and easy it has been for me to keep up with my transactions with this on my PDA. It has helped me keep a closer eye on my bank accounts and also helped me be more aware of my spending habits. This program really is worth trying out.

I consider myself pretty handy with computers and figured that I could migrate programs/data from my old XP machine to my new Win7 PC in an afternoon or so.  But, after catching a good review in Barron's of PCMover I decided that shelling out the $$$s for the program would give me that afternoon back.  How wrong could I be.

PC Mover successfully moved over 400GB of data (pictures/videos) via crossover ethernet cable, although it took over 15 hours.  However, it struggled in transferring many common programs.  iTunes and Mozy (online backup) were the most problematic as PCMover had copied across registry entries from my old 32bit PC on to my new 64bit machine and that created no end of headaches and wasted hours.  I also had to re-install Eye-Fi, Firefox ... and probably Adobe Photoshop Elements ... it's a week after the transfer and I'm still finding problems.

PCMover Support/FAQ is no help.  Luckily there are solutions posted online to help you fix the issues, but this should NOT be happening with paid software!  I can not recommend this software.

I got suckered into buying Microsoft Office for Mac 2008 because my wife's office had upgraded their PCs to whatever the PC version of the latest of Office is, and we wanted to be compatible with the new Word docx files.  Of course, in real life, very few people seem to be using docx files, even in mid-2009, so upgrading to docx is basically pointless. After installing the new 2008 version of Office on our Macs at home, I immediately noticed Word, Excel and PowerPoint programs took longer to open than the 2004 versions.  I also noticed that Word and Excel especially were loaded with a bunch of features that no one really needs and generally distracts from what I'm trying to create on my Mac.  It's as if Microsoft once again answered consumer questions than nobody ever asked.  After using Office 2008 for the Mac for about six months, I finally decided to remove and trash it from my Mac.  I'm back to using the 2004 version and am much happier with software that is easier to use with less distracting bells and whistles that I don't need to type a memo or prepare a spread sheet. My latest experience with another "innovative" Microsoft product helps me better understand why Microsoft stock sells in the low $20's while Apple's price is nearing $170 a share.  I'm glad I'm a Mac, and not a PC, and I'm REALLY GLAD that I own Apple stock.  Is it possible to select "0" stars for an Amazon review?... if so, please change my vote to zero.
Beware.....for some reason the cloud link drops periodically, and when it does (especially with Excel) it's a nightmare to recover from. Otherwise the program works pretty much as advertised.
I like Microsoft Office and would like it even more if I would be able to download my third copy

The only real question is - does this card work? It's the lowest priced way to buy Office 365 so that's a reasonable question.

It's a 100% legit Microsoft issued card. Punch in the code and they take it just like any other card. A few minutes later you have office on 5 computers and 5 tablets. You and your buddies have 100 gig of One Drive to play with, and you can make random Skype calls all over the world for 60 minutes a month.

What happens in a year? Well hopefully you can buy another card, dump in into your account and save some more money. That of course assumes that the giant asteroid misses us and we're all still here ....

If I could give it one star, I would. First of all, reconciling is a mess. They no longer eliminate already-reconciled transactions, nor do they have different columns for debits and credits, so you have to look at a long list of transactions that all look the same to find the one you're attempting to reconcile. Also, reconciling will only go back so far, so if you have an old transaction that has finally cleared, you have to leave reconcile - which is kind of a pain unto itself, find it somewhere, click the reconcile button, then go back to reconcile. I also prefer the register to LOOK like a register. Now, to get all the info I need, I have to squeeze it all into one line since the 2 line format is gone. But today, I'm trying to print a report for the accountant, and there is no "category summary", tho it SAYS 'category summary'. In their report, each category lists EVERY SINGLE transaction for the year. My account doesn't care about all that. He wants the totals. So, either I give him 46 pages to look at, or I have to type the damn thing myself, which kind of negates the point of having Quicken in the first place. Don't give up your Quicken 2006 unless you really have to!!!

Streets & Trips 2005 with GPS is a GREAT product. I have used it on 2 road-trips across Ontario and it performed very well. There were times when the GPS couldn't receive a signal, possibly due to poor weather or tall buildings (I was in Toronto). However, after driving a bit further, the signal usually recovered. During these down-times, I had to use the step-by-step directions and follow the map the old-fashioned way.

In one case, my wife and I took the wrong exit ramp on a busy highway and were able to get back on track very quickly due to the GPS showing we were heading in wrong direction. The "re-calculate from current position" function is worth the price of the GPS alone since it helps you get back on track after taking wrong turns/exits.

Another great feature is that the map re-orients itself to the direction you are heading in, like turning the map yourself.

The only drawback to S&T2005 is you need to have a laptop with a long-lasting battery or car adapter.

For all those people who get lost easily when driving, or have an incredibly bad sense of direction, I can personally recommend you get this. It's worth the value.
Just as described and a Quality Product AAA+++ at a Great Price :)
Perfect for food bloggers.

Hi there.  When I first got this unit I was very excited.  This was after Owning Nuvi 350,660,775t (3) Magallan 4370's and a 4250.  I now tried a Tom Tom 740 live

Overall opinion I wanted to Love it.  When it works correctly it routes much better than the Garmin I'm assuming because of the IQ Routes.  I also like the weather and Gas prices.  Most of all I love the Google Search.  I can just plug in a name of a doctor and it will Find it. (or any other business)  It was much better in finding an address of a house on a block than Navteq.  In otherwords it was right on.  (where 4990 was it was)

What turned me off on this unit was a few things. fundementally The unit does not turn on when you turn the ingition, The gui is complicated (when you are in a rush) It does not list traffic problems when off route and yes it rebooted a few times. What I also didn't like about Tom Tom was the fact that the left turn right turn voice was very confusing, Sometimes it didn't mention the street name and when it told you to turn it was not time to turn yet.  There was also a issue with auto reroute When I didn't listen to Tom Tom it kept silent and late into the route it told me an alturnative way.  With Garmin you can know it's working because the minunite you get off route it says RECALUCATING. So in that area with Garmin I felt more secure.  Even with these flaws I was  willing to live with these issues if my routes were almost perfect.

four times in 3 weeks this thing got me lost.

 When I did a test to my mothers house it didn't leave me in the right development and it was way off by a mile or 2.

For my business I was suppose to go to a client on A1A in Halendale beach Fl it left me in Hollywood. (thank god I know the area)

One time comming from my friends house I wanted to go to a Pizza place The pizza place was off a main intersection on 172 st.  I think it took me down 173 or 174th street, made me go in a circle back to 172 and all the way down.  All I had to do was make a left on 172st and it was on the corner.

Lastly I was going to Miami from Tamarac (Broward County) and I had to keep on 95.  a Fault of mine was I was not paying attention to the street sign but the lane assistance thing said stay in the left lane.  Well it took me off to an exit in a bad area in Miami and I couldn't find my way back to 95.

Other issues When I first got the unit I had to go though Tech support to get my map update and after the update the gas prices was not working so I had to call back to get that resoloved.

Conclusion believe it or not I will miss this Tom Tom maybe I should of waited it out.  because when it worked it was better than Garmin.  But with the Garmin I never did get lost (I can rely on it to get me to where I have to go even though it may not be the best route.)  I will for sure miss google Maps but as a consulation I did purchase MSN direct and believe it or not it has weather,even a radar, The gas prices are more accurate, it has news and stock reports, and movies.  so in that area I gained.  The Garmin is a much easier interface for me to use while driving.  But yes it has it's quarks also but I hope it will improve.  Thank god I have my own good sense of direction so around here for business I really just need to know the local streets.  what I really wanted the relabilty for was when I was out of town.

Magallen all I have to say about it is they all freeze, or the screen is slow.  and with my last one the power adapter broke in 1 week I just don't have time for this.

How do I feel about having a Garmin back.  Lets put it this way I'd love it to be perfect.  But since we sold our country to the rice fields in China that won't happen.  It's good, I feel it could be better.  Tom Tom would of been great if they had a better mapping system.  The idea of routing with iq maps is awsum.  But Garmin takes me on good routes also. The thing about Garmin that made me switch back to them is the reliablity, From what I remember the company was very customer service friendly and they seem to know there stuff.  (I don't know about now) but I do know from past experiences they do improve there products.  As a matter of fact before my 755t got stollen Garmin took me on a round about way to get to mom's 4 months later I got this 765t and it has been corrected.  I know in the future I will be buyiny other GPS's and hopefully then they will have what I'm looking for.  But for now I will stick with this because I've used Garmin for my business for years and for me it seemed to be the least stressful for a varitiy of reasons. which include fuctionality and reliablity in routes.  Poi's that needs to be improved. (thats why I chose this tom tom but with that I even went back to Garmin) So....

With Garmin if I choose I can get Lifetime map updates and also lifetime msn with tom tom it's a 10.00 per month for the service and you have to purchase the maps.  I am hopeing Garmin will start to have maybe a yahoo search or something like the google search, I am also hoping Garmin will have the traffic data on there maps similar to IQ Routes.

This Tom Tom has great Potential But man they have to improve on the small stuff I mean let the unit go on automaticly when you start the car even magallen does that.  How about an answer of we can fix your reboot problem instead of I don't know.  For the kind of money we spent I firmly belive that a accurate lane assistance on 95 would be the least to ask for, And we need less of an error rate of 4 mistakes in 3 weeks.  Great idea on iq routing and it works great but please make it more reliable before selling it to the general public.

The Online window now closes when restarting the program, but it is just a matter of using an Online Center button in the menu bar to get there instead. This is designed for those people who are NOT artists, graphic designers, etc....it should be a little easier for them to use.  It even took me some playing around to figure out some of the oddities, like the number of clicks you have to make to activate a text box so you can make edits, the rendering that looks awful on the screen, but ends up being fine when printed, weird marginal requirements when viewing text that really is "ok" but looks like it's been cut off and missing....it's all really hard to explain.  What is REALLY nice however, are the scrapbooking style pages, images frames, and other nice touches that allow one to really dress things up.  We worked together to make a genealogical photo/story book, and it came out great.  There just seems to be a learning curve that I, as computer savvy person, do not believe should be there for the non computer savvy person.

Argggggghhhhhhh!!!  Enough already!  Norton Security has become the MALWARE that it's supposed to protect me against!

Unless this major bug gets fixed soon, I will NOT be purchasing another Norton product. Norton has lost its focus on this product and forgets what its software is supposed to do.  It's time to leave it behind.

You still have to pay $19.99 per state tax return you e-file. When I finished my sixth tax return (I was wrong and thought it offered six free federal e-filings), I went through the process, paid the state e-filing fee only to be informed that I had reached the limit. TurboTax downloaded another one for me, but I couldn't transfer the tax data I had already filled out, and I couldn't import it to their online returns since it was 2008 data. TurboTax said I would have to buy another version and do the sixth tax return all over on another computer. I couldn't use my free MD state download or my paid Missouri state download since I had to do it on another computer. So I purchased this one just to do one tax return and discovered that downloading one state cost $39.99. Since I had already printed out the Missouri state return from my computer, I skimped and only downloaded MD state return and will paper file the Missouri one. I still had one unused state e-filing on my previous TurboTax but was told that the two go hand in hand, so you have to e-file the same federal & state, you can't use an unfiled state e-file on another return. Bottom line is that original version I purchased (see above link) with the free state is now around $41. This one cost $34.39 + $39.99 for one state = $74.38. Crazy prices - I wish I had purchased the $41 w/free state download and saved myself some bucks! Also, since there are five people in my home (only 2 returns as yet though) and friends asked me to do their return, TurboTax should have flexibility so that if you exceed the five limit, you can reload more and not have to pay all over again for another software package, another 2nd state download etc. I am going to suggest this to them for next year.

TurboTax said my state submittal was complete, and then it was rejected by the state.  Then I spent another $25 re-submitting due to TurboTax's ineptitude, because TurboTax's instructions were impossible to understand.
If I could give this a zero I would. I bought the online code version, and the code was invalid. That was a avlot of money for nothing! Very disappointed!

This is my original review before the above came to light.  The product remains five stars for me personally.

I am just discovering all the refinements which have gone into Snow Leopard.  However, what I want to comment on is the most important aspect to me.  I came to my Macbook from years of working on PCs.  One good thing PCs did for me was that I became quite a proficient little techie but that was because I was forced to do so.  I lost count of the amount of times I had to reinstall my operating system due to an overall system crash, an Internet Explorer flaw which crashed the whole OS, viruses or trojans or other problems which got past my virus protection software, etc., etc., When I went over to Mac, I was able to retire from being a self taught techie.  I have to do just about zilch on my macbook in order to keep it running well.  I have now used Tiger, Leopard and Snow Leopard.  Each one is an improvement over the last.  There is no bloating factor.  I don't have a bunch of extra software on here which I don't need.  In fact, I picked up about 18 GB of space by switching to Snow Leopard from Leopard.  Snow Leopard is working perfectly for me 24/7 and I have not really had to think about adapting to it.  It is so intuitive that I just find myself doing so automatically.

I always liked the finder and I like it even better now in Snow Leopard.  I've been doing great searches within my folders, getting wonderfully sized images as my thumbnails plus Quick Look is better than ever.  As I set all of my preferences for the whole OS, I discovered that certain things, which were more complicated to do in Leopard, are now simpler to do.  Some specs were removed entirely and macbook just does them quietly on its own in the background, which is fine by me.  I do not miss the hours I spent reading computer manuals as I tried to cope with being a PC user.

After the installation, everything still worked just fine.  I was able to just pick off where I had left off without missing a beat.  I have a David Pogue missing manual book sitting next to me but have yet to open it as I've run into no problems.

Best of all, it was really cheap to buy.  I've never had such a cheap OS yet it is so slick!!!!

It is hard for me to imagine why you would not want Snow Leopard on your Mac.  If I run into such a reason, I will come back and edit this review to include it!

When clicking on the tabs, it sets up across the toolbar, all of the functions of that particular tab. Once viewed, you not only see the words of the functions, but also, small example graphs and images of what that functions does. The load times seem to be much quicker than what I had in the 2003 version. In Outlook, setting up accounts, maintaining names and addresses is much easier too. The only annoying part of Office 2007 that comes to mind is, one can only choose from 3 color schemes. In my honest opinion, I like having the standard color look like previous versions and as my taste goes with this, I only like the black setup only.

I've used Quicken for perhaps 18 years. I'm invested/trapped into using it, mainly because no other program offers the hope of helping me track many different types of accounts--401K, 403b, 529, checking, savings, etc.

I say "hope," but Quicken 2012 still won't download automatically transactions for 403b and 529 (student savings plans) accounts. 403b plans are, to the person who's using one, identical in nature to 401K plans, in that they invest in mutual funds and they use mutual fund companies (Fidelity, Vanguard, etc.). My wife and I work at a hospital with a Fidelity 403b plan, and because I try to maintain proper investment diversity, each of our accounts has about 10 transactions per month. That's 20 transactions that I have to enter manually, using Quicken's awful transactions utility. Our kid's 529 plan receives only five transactions per month, but those too must be entered manually.

Vanguard's 529 plan says "Please note: We worked closely with Intuit to be able to offer Quicken download capability; however, we were unable to come to a suitable agreement. The costs of offering download capability into Quicken for 529 accounts were too high, and introducing this feature would negatively impact expenses associated with the program." In other words, Intuit wanted too much money. I don't know what the issue was/is with 403b plans, but I can only assume that Intuit wants too much money for those downloads, too.

I've found that I have allowed the onerous task of entering these transactions manually to affect my investment choices (arg--do I really want to diversify as much as I should, if I have to enter all those transactions in Quicken?) and it diminishes my ability to track performance (because I often let the task of entering them slide for a few months, and then I don't have a clear picture of what my investments are doing).

The utility for entering transactions doesn't help, either--it's a separate box from the register, and if you've got a browser window on one side of your screen and Quicken scrunched up on the other, you can't see what gets entered into the register until you close it. And in Quicken 2012, it's actually worse, because if you change the investment type (say, from "add shares" to "reinvest
dividends"), it will revert the date to a past transaction date, so you have to keep a very close eye on that date. It was already very difficult to keep track of the dates, funds, share amounts, share prices and transaction totals, and this just makes the task even more onerous.

One of the new features in Quicken 2012 is supposed to be a new larger font option, but Quicken has allowed you to customize the font size for a while now--except in the Investment section (and perhaps others). In the investment section, you can't change the font type or the font size, with all those teeny transactions, that's where the feature would really be useful. If you in a checking or savings register, you can adjust that font size, but you have to dig into a preferences menu--no easy-access buttons, as are often offered on web pages, and no ability to hold down your control button and spin your mouse wheel to increase/decrease the font size.

This is just one of the ways in which Quicken 2012 seems to put lipstick on the pig: Intuit touts some fancy new tools--for example, in its spiffed-up budgeting tool and redesigned debt-reduction tool--but behind these okay-looking interfaces you'll find the same old 1995-era interface. For example, if you try to edit a budget amount in the new interface, you can't edit directly on the screen; Quicken 2012 pops up a dialog box that looks that same as it did in 1995. Enter the amount, click OK, and the interface shifts back to the top of the screen, rather than returning you to the same spot as you were in. The other improvements in this year's upgrade are similarly tepid.

For the past 10 years, the only reason to upgrade Quicken is to maintain the ability to download transactions online--and it's becoming increasingly difficult for me to use it for that. But no other tool offers it either. I was hoping that Intuit's acquisition of Mint.com would bring some new life to Quicken, but apparently, my hope was unfounded. It's the same as it always was.

OK.  So I read all the "spyware" reviews, and I read the manufacturer's response, and I read some of the other reviews, and I decided to buy the product.  I mean hey, it's $25, I can risk it.  If for nothing else, just to give an accurate review of the product, not just write a "review" never having read the terms myself, nor having tried the product myself.

So here's the deal.  "The truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help me God."  I won't swear on my grandmother's grave, because my grandmother's still alive.  Both of them.  So yeah, you get the point.  Here's an actual product review, not just a bunch of nonsense.

Regarding the "spyware," it doesn't do  much.  In fact, it doesn't do any different than virtually any other program on your computer that can interact with the internet by requiring a license, such as Microsoft Office, Adobe anything, any internet browser, any IM program, heck, even the OS itself.  It verifies that the license is legit and that you're not using a fraudulent copy.  It gathers non-personal, anonymous information regarding your interests so that Corel knows how to properly revise their software for future updates to meet the needs of their clients.  If changes "default settings" by allowing it to validate the license and interact with the internet to see if there are any product updates, security updates, etc. that you need in order for your program to run efficiently.

Here's what it doesn't do.  It doesn't gather any personal information.  It doesn't sell that information that it doesn't acquire to third parties.  It doesn't spam your inbox.  It doesn't constantly tie up a whole lot of memory.  (You can view the amount of memory it is using by going to the task manager.)  It doesn't automatically make it to where you can't use another program as the default program to open pictures and such.  It doesn't bypass your firewall and shut it down so that you're computer's at risk for viruses.  It doesn't access your camera and microphone and record video of you while you're doing stuff you're not supposed to do in the first place.  It doesn't monitor your credit card transactions to steal your numbers.  It doesn't monitor your key strokes.  I think you get the point.  It's not spyware anymore than Microsoft Office is.

OK, so the actual product.  It's a decent product.  The user submitted images are really what it can do, and it's really not that difficult to do them.  There are things you can do with it that the beginninger, never having used a photo editing program before, can easily learn.  There are intermediate things that are a little harder, but give a decent challenge to a non-pro.

However, it's not really a professional product.  If you're an extremely good amateur, as in, if you don't own a business and aren't using it as your primary source of income, then the product has a lot of good features for you, and is well worth the price.  For a business, it might be a good backup tool if you don't want to purchase a license of Photoshop for every computer.  It's definitely worth the price, and for some simply things it is a lot easier to do here in PSP than Photoshop.  I'd say it's a whole lot better than the basic editing that you can do with iPhoto for the Mac, and I use that quite a bit when I'm not needing to do anything with layers or combining images.  (I run Windows 7 on my Mac a bit, so that's where I can use PSP.)

Overall, I'd say it's a great product to do simple things with very quickly and easily.  For advanced things, it's still a pretty good product, worth a 4-star review; but for the really advanced things, where you need specialized filters that you purchase separately for Photoshop, it doesn't match up with Photoshop.  However, for what I do in taking pictures of weddings, children, families, scenery, sports, and products for advertisements on eBay; it's worth the money by far.  I'm not a professional, but I make perhaps $1,000-$3,000 a year on photography and graphic design.  I'm not going to replace Photoshop with it, nor am I going to use it most of the time, but if I'm running my Windows for any reason, it would by far be the default program to which I would turn.

So there you have it folks!  My review in a nutshell.  (I hope everyone brought a nutcracker...)  Hope it sheds some light on the actual product, not just a bunch of spam reviews by people who have never used it, bought it, or even read the license agreement for themselves.

"Create a new folder on the desktop.

1. Open quicken program
2. Click on File
3. Click on Backup
4. Click on Browse
5. Select the new folder created on the desktop
6. It will backup the file to the new folder
7. Right click on new folder and then send it to the CD.
8. It will backup the file to the CD. "

In other words - backup to hard drive and copy to CD. Yeah - I figured that out myself.

I tried the competitors' products, most notably the Norton products, and I wasn't as impressed with them as I am with Trend Micro. While the competitors all work well, they're also quite bloated and spend a lot of time taking over your system, installing toolbars without offering a path to deactivate them (I hate toolbars in my Internet browser), and asking too much in terms of violating privacy.

Trend Micro is different. It's more streamlined, doesn't hog resources while protecting your PC, and allows you the end-user control that major competitors don't seem to think you should have. Trend Micro installs easily, and updates quietly in the background. It scans and repairs just as smoothly.

My only complaint about this package is that when you install it as a Pro upgrade to a registered, subscribed Trend Micro Antivirus package (the basic version of their paid products), it doesn't take the months you have remaining on your current subscription into account. For example, I had six months left on my Trend Micro Antivirus subscription, and once I installed this Pro package, I had one year, instead of getting one year and six months. My six months are gone, replaced by the new year's worth.  I would like to have seen them find a way to give me everything I paid for in the lesser version, but then add the year on top of that instead of replacing it.

That issue aside, the package handles everything I need on Windows 7, even being smart enough to give me the choice of using Trend Micro firewall or Windows firewall, and disabling the one that's not being used. In contrast, one of the competitors' products actually asks you to turn off Windows firewall prior to running their installer. Trend Micro did it right; That made it easy, and they made it work WITH your operating system instead of working against it.

No complaints here. Top-notch product. Better than the free antivirus packages (way more features) and better than the bigger-name office standards which have grown into bloated, self-indulgent, non-intuitive packages. Trend Micro just *gets it*.

Adobe Captivate started life as Flashcam from Nexus Concepts 2000, then became RoboDemo when acquired by eHelp of San Diego. Macromedia then bought eHelp and renamed the application Captivate. Finally, Adobe acquired Macromedia. So, you could say this application's been around. That is a testament to the usefulness of the concept. Unfortunately, the execution leaves a little to be desired. But before you are completely turned off to this little diamond in the rough, read on to see if it's worth the shortcomings.

To be honest, I've never before used an application specifically aimed at training or demonstration on the web. I typically publish help files in PDF (Adobe Acrobat) format as necessary. That doesn't always help when trying to train someone to use a content management system, or when developing custom solutions for less-than-computer-literate users. So, I went looking for a way to present a more visual experience. Enter Captivate!

First, the good stuff.

Captivate is incredibly easy to use. Just install it and you are ready to start recording presentations. Spend a few moments to learn the shortcut keys, and you can do pretty much everything you need to do for a simple follow-along style demo. When recording is done, you can edit slides, add audio and video, and modify cursor movement. All of this is pretty much as easy as using Power Point.

Recording screenshots is done in a couple of different ways; manually with a key press, or automatically when you click or drag the mouse. Dragging can also automatically record full motion clips. Configuration of these options is quite simple, and offered on a popup window when you start recording a new project. After trying both the automated and manual methods, I chose to capture screenshots by key press, with automatic recording while dragging. This gave me quite a bit of control and more flexibility in choosing what elements to capture, especially because I tend to jump around a lot while working. Rather than grabbing every action then having to remove the useless, incorrect, or unnecessary excursions, I can just take the images that best show the task at hand.

It is also possible to import slides from a PowerPoint presentation, which is good news for those trainers and presenters who have existing libraries of content they want to migrate to Captivate. Export options include standalone executable, zip or swf file, and there is the ability to integrate with Adobe Connect. This feature alone might be worth the price of admission.

Editing the slides is pretty simple for most tasks. For example, you can add highlight regions, move the cursor position and path, and control some effects as well as the amount of time a slide is on the screen. Add some static or animated text to draw attention to important points or areas, and you're golden. There are a number of built-in Flash animation effects for type as well as mouse clicks. You can build more of your own to enhance your presentation or share them with others. Of course, this requires Flash or something that will output the SWF format properly.

Training interactions are also quick to set up thanks to a great mapping view. This lets you see the paths and possible choices when using branching interactions. Captivate can also track responses for SCORM/AICC compliance, a real boon for trainers. Add this to Adobe Connect and you can distribute your training and courses across the world. Literally.

For web work, you will have to pay special attention to file size. Adding extra screenshots, or any audio and video, will significantly increase your file size, in many cases becoming almost unusable for web presentations. A simple demo can quickly get above a few MB, so it will be important to spend some time fine tuning your demo and removing anything that adds weight without having a good reason for being there.

Unfortunately, there are some down sides. The application doesn't feel mature due to lots of bugs. One of the most annoying manifestations is an 'unsticky' window or menu. When this happens, menu items fail to work properly since they disappear before a selection can be made. Typically, the only recourse is to relaunch the application. Sometimes, it saves you the effort of closing it by spontaneously crashing. Save often. Very often.

Another difficulty I have is the lack of flexibility in modifying slides within Captivate. While it is possible to include mouse movements and text entry animations, it is difficult to synthesize them. In fact, it's just not possible in some cases. I would love to see the ability to just place a cursor and path arbitrarily on a given slide, to create the path as a standard Bezier vector for editing, as well as text field examples. Going further, being able to split out menu items on the slides, like drop downs or highlights, would make the files smaller and thus easier to distribute. On the plus side, you can take advantage of round-trip capabilities with Adobe Photoshop, which helps cut down file size and give lots of room for tweaking and custom edits.

Suggested retail from Adobe's site is about $600. For a business or organization that needs to produce training and demo materials, this is a pretty reasonable price for the available features. While there are other solution out there for free, and some that actually cost more, Adobe has a good balance, and if history is any indicator, they will continue to craft this application into a truly indispensable tool for trainers.

The stability issues notwithstanding, Captivate is a very impressive tool. For a full list of features, check out the Adobe Captivate product page.

Overall, I am pretty happy with Captivate. The features are unlike any package I've used, and it's almost embarrassingly simple to create engaging simulations and training. I anxiously await a dot release to fix the problems. Download the demo and build yourself some presentations. And keep an eye out for fixes.

For example, can't I just hit the spacebar 6 times to make a big space right there? With Wordperfect you can. You can make really intricate charts without having to really learn how to do stuff...it is just really much more intuitive than Word. I have even changed the font on one single character in seconds. I couldn't be more happy with wordperfect.

Test System: PowerMac G4 AGP 400 MHz with 896 MB RAM and a Radeon 8500
OS: Mac OS 10.2.3 (build 6G30)
While Britannica 2003 runs on OS X, it is not truly native.  Rather, it is a Java based application designed on the Windows platform.  Java is cross-platform, but without some minor changes to optimize an application for the Mac the experience may be poor.  Unfortunately, Brtiannica did not make that effort... and it shows.
Installation was a hassle.  The first installation program you see (and the one the readme tells you to use) fails, you have to open the folder "Extract" then "MacOSX" to find a working one.  The full install requires that you switch CDs midway and ejects the first disk, but fails to unmount it in the Finder.  It also ejects the second disk when finished without unmounting.  The installer suffered an unexpected quit as it finished too.  Attempting to unmount the ghost disk icons hangs the Finder and requires a relaunch (not a restart).
The application took 19 seconds to load, but once loaded performance was generally acceptable.  Slower than a native application, but faster than a broadband internet connection and this is on a 3 year old computer, albeit with lots of RAM.
Unfortunately, the interface is completely non-Macintosh.  The menu bar is not utilized, instead File, Edit, etc. are stuck in the application.  "Britannica Help" under the Help menu does not work.  Additionally, key equivalents are still mapped for Windows, so some standard command-key combination won't work and control instead of command must be used for those that do.  These are serious oversights and violate Apple's interface guidelines.
Rather than letting the OS draw the windows, Britannica decided to create it's own windowing system within the application, complete with desktop.  This system is inferior both functionally and graphically to Aqua.  Additionally, this means the application's window takes almost the whole screen and is not resizable.  This makes working with multiple applications needlessly cumbersome.
While text can be cut and paste into other applications, pictures and multimedia cannot.  This needlessly restricts content when working on a report in anything but the limited sub-application Research Organizer.
Searching is decent, but is not very forgiving with spelling.  A spell check button is available that opens an application modal dialog with pull down menus of suggested replacement words for each one you entered.  But it isn't that good for spell checking.  For instance, typing "attak" gives you attack, but also 90 other seemingly random words covering the gamut between "Athos" and "wadi."
The Knowledge Navigator has potential to be a useful search/browse tool but, like much of the interface, is poorly implemented.  It is a data association program which starts with a ring of 10 topics.  Clicking on one moves it to the center and surrounds it with up to ten related topics, this can be repeated to refine a search or simply browse ideas.  Unfortunately, the designer decided that it needed each topic needs to float out from the central one and individually take its place in the ring.  The effect is up to 17 seconds of animation each time you change topics.  The eye-candy gets old real fast when it interferes with your work.
The interactive timeline is a nice feature that lets you view key events in 14 subjects chronologically and provides links to more information.  It took 8 seconds to load, but (much more aggravating) 10 seconds simply to view all timeline subjects you may select by scrolling through a list at the bottom at a fixed, sedate speed.
The Atlas is similar to a globe in detail.  Maps only go to the country level with more detailed maps for US states and the occasional random area.  Clicking on major cities and regions gives a brief article.
The program includes Merriam-Websters Collegiate Dictionary and Thesaurus, but their entries are accessible only through the main encyclopedia search, no separate applications.
The text of the encyclopedia itself seems good.  Multimedia is weak.  There are only 55 Quicktime files, most fewer than 20 seconds and only one exceeding one minute.  Some of the video is poor in quality and the typical resolution is only 160x120 for video and 320x240 for animations.  Additional multimedia content on Britannica's website is oddly available only in Windows Media or Real Player format.
This encyclopedia does have some good information and, despite it's many flaws, may offer you more rapid access to some reliable material than the internet.  However, the interface is very poor and non-standard and may prove frustrating.  With a little bit of effort Britannica could have made this a far better Macintosh product.  It is not horribly expensive, but I would be inclined to pass on it.  World Book 2003 Mac OS X - Jaguar Edition is the competing encyclopedia for the Macintosh OS X and, while more expensive, is probably worth a look.

I found Final Draft 9 to be an excellent tool to develop a screenplay especially for "Rookies."  My background is general contracting. After a forty year career in the building industry I retired and decided to develop and write a screenplay. A friend of mine introduced me to Final Draft. I purchased Final Draft 9 and with a little tutoring I immediately started to write the screenplay. Will my story hit the "Big Screen?" Only time will tell, but without Final Draft 9 I would have fumbled through the writing process. I drafted the screenplay in only twenty days! I would have spent significantly more time and effort. Final Draft 9 made me look like a "Pro." Well done gentlemen.

Jerry Daniele
Albuquerque, New Mexico

After having my new laptop hacked Black Friday, I lost desktop system. The hacker had not only stolen all my data but had fried my home computer and compromised every other electronic device in my home! I was completely unaware....I had been online shopping and was busy as the hackers were in the background patiently waiting to drain each bank account and credit card I had. I had top of the line anti virus software on my brand new laptop so I was not expecting how easy it really was for someone in another country to come into my home without having to worry about running from the police or any neighborhood watch.
If it would not have been for my dear friend coming to my aid to fix malicious attack on my family I would have never have found out about this amazing product. I installed one system onto each computer into my home as well as my business. It is also available for cell phones as well which is ingenious! What is your safety worth to you? I can promise, it's worth a lot more than what this cost.....this system is priceless.....
For what it cost, this purchase is easy and pays for it's self just in safety factor alone.

I have used turbo tax for over 10 years and really like the product, until last year.  My wife owns farmland in a state we no longer live in.  For 4 years we were not declaring taxes in that state become turbo tax did not indicate we needed to. Instead, we were declaring taxes for the state in which we live.  This past year turbo tax prompted us that we needed to pay tax on our income in the second state as well.  I ended up having to re-file my taxes in both states for the past 4 years.  I used a CPA to do this.  Now it would have been a wash since I could have deducted the taxes paid to another state but I ended up having to pay about $500 in interest and penalties.  I guess the bottom line is: you don't know what you don't know, and if you don't have somebody who does know (or a program), mistakes will be made.  I use a CPA now and the cost is only about 75% more than turbotax.

The Roxio Easy VHS to DVD software is very resource intense and requires way more than the specifications lead you to believe. I read with great interest evaluations that said it worked perfectly as described all the way to it was a piece of crap that never worked. I found that a 2.4 GHz P4 processor and 2gig of memory did not work. The audio was way out of sync and video was quite jerky. Operating this software in this configuration was far from satisfactory. Now the good news, running this Roxio software with 3 gig of memory and a dual core 2.0 GHz processor worked flawlessly. It worked as described in the documentation, with no issues. This tells you what won't work and what will. Probably some where between these machines is the breaking point but use this information as a guide. In all cases I was not running any other programs and I was copying the information to an external hard drive. The results did not change between Windows XP and Windows 7. Hope this information is of some use.

I hate this version.  I purchased this version for burning picture slide DVDs and burning music CDs.  Well, for burning picture slide DVDs this version is a ripoff.  This version does not let you edit your pictures once you've lined them up to burn them.  Also, this part was what took the cake for me.  Adding transitions to my picture slide DVD made me very upset because this version shows me a huge listing of transitions only not to allow me to use them.  I clicked one of the many transitions and it displays a huge message saying that I don't have the transition pack and automatically takes me to the page where I can buy Nero Classic 2015 which is what I have.  As for burning music CDs, that task too is problematic.  The choice for burning CDs the ones you can play on your regular DVD players, this Nero Classic version gives choices only if you want to burn the CD as Jukebox version which will only play on your computer and not on traditional CD players.  Then, burning as MP3 music files, Nero Classic burns the MP3 files on CDs but when I tried playing these, again these would only play on my computer and not on my MP3 boombox.  My boombox plays both traditional music files and MP3 files.  So you see, I'm very upset with Nero.  And to top it, I looked up how to contact them for help.  I found out that they charge $1.29 to help me on the telephone.  Really?  I never expected to have such a hard time with this Nero Classic 2015 software.  I mean, I'm not a computer geek but I always thought I could figure things out on my own.  I mean, I had a previous Nero version for a long time and that version did everything for me.  I loved it.  This is why I purchased this Classic 2015 version because I thought it would be everything I had before in my previous version plus more options.  I was WRONG!  I ended up with more limitations than with any software I had ever worked with.  SO, BEWARE IF YOU'RE CONSIDERING BUYING THIS NERO CLASSIC 2015. Let me start off by saying that I am a native English speaker, and I am also an ESL teacher.  I purchased this program so that I could use it to supplement my classes and give my students some extra practice.  It has its  up points and down points.  Let me explain what I think of this program  from a teacher's point of view.  THE GOOD: 1) Like other "Learn to  Speak" titles I would have to say that its strongest point is helping  students learn vocabulary and pronunciation.  It has some good vocabulary  lists, a gauge that allows students to see how their recorded pronunciation  compares to a native speaker, and wonderful simulated conversations that  allow learners to practice English in a very life like manner.  2) It has  several cultural movies about cities in the United States.  They are very  enjoyable and teach students about geography, history and U.S. culture  while allowing them to practice their listening skills.  3) If students  want to study something other than the lessons included on the four CDs,  they can download additional lessons from the Internet.  It is very easy to  do, takes about ten minutes, and there are several topics to choose from.  THE BAD: 1) The dictionary is good for nothing except helping students to  pronounce words.  Since this program is entirely in English, there is no  translation for the words.  It really is quite a useless dictionary!  2)  You can't print anything!  I thought it would be nice to print out the  words and expressions so that students could take them home to practice  them, but alas, you cannot.  3) The program (including instructions) is  entirely in English.  Don't get me wrong, there are many benefits to this,  but if a student is using this for self-study I don't think they will get  far before tiring of trying to understand all the English instructions.  (For Spanish speakers I would suggest "Hablemos Ingles" from this  same company.)  4) This program really is for lower level learners (first  and second year.)  My advanced students enjoyed the cultural movies, and  found the simulated conversations novel, but the rest wasn't helpful to  them.  5) If you already have version 7.0, then don't bother upgrading to  this one.  Only the simulated conversations are better.  The movies and  lessons seem to be the same - only organized a bit differently and in a  more confusing manner.  OVERALL:  This is a good program if being used to  supplement a current course or to give learners extra practice.  I wouldn't  recommend it for self-study because lower level students might have a hard  time with the English instructions, and more advanced students would find  it too easy.  Definitely don't upgrade from version 7.0!  If you are  thinking about getting this program I would actually recommend that you get  version 7.0 - you can find it for a much cheaper price, it is very nearly  the same and it is organized better.

Microsoft continues to shield attacks about Vista, though many are based on heresay and preconceived notions of the MSFT culture.  If you sit down and give Vista a try, and if you get a new PC anywhere anymore you probably don't have a choice, you might not have any complaints.

First of all, a lot of the early reports of bugs in the program have been addressed and fixed in SP1, so users should not rely on what their friends have told them about Vista...as the ONLY source of information.

Secondly, my thoughts are based on my experience in Windows.  I will admit that I am an avid PC user and tend to be a little more friendly to MSFT than some other people because I am very comfortable in the Windows environment.  But with that said, Vista showcases Microsoft's worst innovative technique.  With each release of Windows or Office, Microsoft has been trying to make the user experience easier.  They say, "We know what you are doing so we will go ahead and do it for you."  And often times they are wrong.  They are taking some of the organization away and making things hard to find and displaying what some algorithm assumes you were looking for.  And I wish Microsoft would stop doing this.

I prefer Windows to MacOS.  I like that things follow a simple organizational pattern and everything can be neatly put away in Windows.  But don't worry, it's still there, you just have to wade through some new Vista flare to get there.

And that is my biggest gripe with Vista.  Rather than keeping the ease of use that Windows XP has and just beefing up other areas, the company seems to have opted instead for making Vista a mutated product.  I wish they would eliminate some of the confusion and just call it Microsoft Vista and remove Windows from the product name.

I'll adjust to it like anything else and before long Vista will be the new standard.

I purchased iDevice Magic Platinum as I was frustrated by the limitations of iTunes. However, this product makes iTunes look very professional indeed.

I am running Windows 7 64bit and my iOS devices are on iOS7.0.3. I used this program only with my iPhone 4S as there was no way I was going to connect any other device after this experience!

The first thing after installation this morning was to tell me that there was an update. I had just put in the long, complex serial number and registered it online. I downloaded the new version to find that I had to put the serial number in again and register again. It then kept crashing, so I logged off and rebooted my PC. After that I launched it again and once again had to put in the serial number and register a third time! After that it seemed to keep it. However, nothing seems to work correctly with the program. I decided to make a ringtone, so went through the procedure and hey presto a ring tone shows up against my phone, but it is nowhere to be found on the phone itself. I found an option which appeared to let me copy it to the phone, but it still was not there.

Next, I thought I would back up my photos to the computer. What photos? Despite having hundreds of photos on the phone in the camera roll, iDevice Magic refused to display any at all. No photos, no photo albums, NOTHING!

Next was the fact that as I don't use an administrator account all the time on my machine, it set up all the default storage spaces for me in the Admin account instead of the account I was using and refused to change them! OK, so I thought "I've had enough of this!" I rebooted the PC and then fired up iTunes. iTunes promptly told me that it could not read the configuration information from my phone. Presumably it had been corrupted by iDevice Magic. iTunes told me that I had to do a retore from the summary screen. This is not just a restore from backup, it means back to factory default config! This means downloading and installing iOS7.0.3 from scratch and then restoring all my data from a backup! Luckily, I backed the phone up immediately before installing iDevice Magic.

So now, thanks to this product screwing my iPhone completely, I am sitting waiting for many hours for all my contacts, 85 apps, 7760 music files, plus, photos, videos, etc to be restored to my phone.

Not an experience that would make me recommend this product to anyone. In fact, I would advise people to steer well clear of it! I've just called the vendor and got a full refund.

Finally, Microsoft gets it.  Windows 8 is a transitional operating system in a lot of ways.  It may be slow to be adopted, but once touch screens become the norm I believe it will help complete the transition for the PC to move into new territory, the same thing Apple has been pioneering for years with their products.  Of course, there will still be a need for a keyboard and mouse occasionally, but computing is moving into a new era of freedom with mobility and touch screens.  Interfaces are being simplified but as evidenced with iPad apps, the creativity, versatility and fun has increased.  Now, with Windows 8, we get a glimpse of the future with the Metro UI and classic Windows desktop combined into a simplified interface.  In a matter of minutes I was switching back and forth between the Start screen and the desktop.. and finally there's a real use for the START key, which I've never used before until now.

I noticed immediately, the OS has been streamlined.  Where Windows 7 feels like a monster, Windows 8 feels like all the fat has been trimmed, giving more horsepower under the hood.  You will notice a big performance boost.  Gone are the unnecessary menus, replaced with a few simple options.  Basically what they've done is transformed Windows into something it should've been years ago.

I found that there was only a handful of software compatibility issues, which weren't a big issue since I didn't use them regularly anyway.  I think you'll find most software will remain compatible with the new OS.  Microsoft has a list on their site you can use to verify.

As with previous Windows upgrades the sound card (SB X-Fi Xtreme Gamer) wasn't recognized, but I was able to install the latest SB beta drivers and get sound up and going within minutes, after a reboot.

I've only been using it for a couple hours, but I am impressed with the new direction.  A lot of people might scoff at the changes, but you have to consider that Windows hasn't changed that much in the last 15 years.  People won't want to adopt a new platform easily.  I believe that Microsoft has a real winner with this new OS.  It's transitional in that it uses two interfaces, the desktop and Metro, so what I would look for is for future OS's to move more toward weaning people off of their peripherals and embracing touch screen technology for their computing needs.

The performance boost alone is well worth the upgrade to Windows 8.  You won't believe the difference.  Microsoft wins in a big way and I hope they continue in this direction, it's the future of computing.

UPDATE 11/14/12
*Windows has native support for ISO files, but when burning a bootable ISO, it sticks the ISO contents in a subfolder on the CD rather than writing the ISO as it was originally intended, thus I burned a disc I couldn't use because all of the contents were in a dated subfolder.  You would think in this day and age Microsoft would have added in common-sense support for various file types, so that their operating system would be the most inclusive and innovative, but it seems Microsoft still has a long way to go in OS design and common-sense.
*There is no shutdown button on the desktop.  You have to log yourself out, then shut down.  There is a workaround to add a button to the desktop and the Start page, but you shouldn't have to do this.  More lack of common sense in design of a new OS and its interface.
*SkyDrive appears to cause crashes in a key piece of software I use when I go to upload a file to a server.  So either I disable SkyDrive or I can't upload to files like I need to.  Good thing I'm not using SkyDrive at the moment, but what if I wanted to?  Yet another thing you have to use regedit to fix.
*I'm 3 weeks in, using Windows 8, and I'm starting to see that there really isn't a reason to upgrade from Windows 7, unless you want the extra bells and whistles.  Just keep in mind this is a transitioning operating system and the interface has done away with things you're used to.
*I did the upgrade on two PC's, keeping my files but deleting the old OS (Windows 7).  When I was done I was pleasantly surprised to see some apps stayed on my desktop and ran fine, as well as my Windows Live Mail, which after a new install had all of my previous mail settings and loaded up without a need for configuration.

In all, it's open to interpretation.  Microsoft continues to release OS's with features and design that beg the question "What were they thinking?" or "Why didn't they think of this/that; go the extra mile?".  The other thing I don't like and Windows 8 is the Start page is chock full of Microsoft services powered by Bing.  I don't use Bing for anything.  It would be nice to be able to customize those features with ones I want.  Maybe we'll see that as the OS matures.

If you are a current Quicken user faced with a forced upgrade, version 2010 is better than at least, 2007.  upgrade only when necessary.  My upgrades this decade were in 2004 and 2007.

As a heavy user since 1988, I've seen a lot change with Quicken, many have been painful.  Versions this decade are the least problematic.  Periodic upgrades do make sense given its Internet centric operation because HTML, encryption, security protocols, and more, have evolved much and Quicken must adopt these changes.  Alas, to users most of these are invisible and behind the scenes.  In 2010, Quicken now uses the .NET framework for coding, a mixed blessing, as it consumes more memory, resources and disk space to add capability and stability.  Computers should find these added needs inconsequential if these machines run games and 720p movies easily.  I've not had problems with data syncing, slow response, bugs, lost data, corrupt files etc., despite my 4 year old computer and continuous data going back to 1985.

I've never upgraded to a first release of a new version to avoid bugs, nor overwrite a prior version.  Always make a full system backup before installation, a system restore point just before installation, then a fresh install, then import the prior data file as a copy, keeping the old file intact.  This leads to the least, if not problem free upgrade and an effortless path back to the old version should the upgrade bomb.  Although I received 2010 Release 1.0, online files were available to upgrade my 2010 to Release 4.0.

The GUI design has remain unchanged, and clearly noticeable improvements and editing aids are welcome, BUT not worth paying for.

Quicken does make effortless a core function of personal finance, quick retrieval and reliable storage of data, editing and later analysis via reports.  In the past decade, data retrieval has been nearly flawless; duplicate entries are increasingly rare even if you overlap a data set, say after syncing manually then later add data using a QFX file.  However, Quicken has many shortcomings that should have been fixed decades ago.  Quicken has  sub-optimally organized or thought out functions. Its not intuitive where a function is, several do the same thing or are poorly thought out.  For example, there are 3 ways to write electronic checks that do the same thing differently: through a 1990s "online banking" interface, the checking register, or a separate checkbook app.  Attachments to register entries, such as jpgs of checks, can be encrypted individually, however you can see the files whether encrypted or not, the annunciator is poorly located so its not immediately clear if attachments are encrypted, and this option implies Quicken data files are not encrypted entirely, a serious oversight.  There is also suggestion from Elcomsoft, that a backdoor exists for decoding Quicken data file passwords.  Luckily, one can separately encrypt files or drive partitions using Windows options or 3rd party programs.

The new user or light Quicken user should know there are several free personal finance managers available for download that read Quicken formats.  I've tried some of them but they lack Quicken's overall flexibility, and they are similar to early versions of Quicken. Thus, if your needs are simple like budgeting, then tracking income, expense and some investing, there maybe free alternatives.  Should you decide to move to Quicken later, these programs allow exports into the Quicken format.

A software publisher like Intuit can't leave well enough alone. They'd go out of business if they did that, so they keep releasing new versions of products that have already reached perfection or something close to it. Or, as is the case with Quicken, the older versions simply worked.

  Now I finally got around to upgrading to Quicken Home & Business 2007. It runs without crashing - but most of the new features seem to be advertising for Intuit products and services.

  What used to be transparent features, such as downloading credit card transactions and importing them into your accounts is given a fancy name ("web connect") and obfuscated. Try looking up "qfx" file in the Quicken Help system. Nothing really useful. Try looking up "importing credit card data" and you get hundreds of results. It appears that they scooped up everything from their online forums and dumped into their help file. It doesn't work well.

  I finally found the answer I needed: don't fix it if it ain't broken. Once I thoroughly learn this version of Quicken, I will not update again until there is absolutely no choice. If anything, either Intuit should bring out a version with fewer "features" or someone should seize the market opportunity for a product that simply works.

Jerry

summed up the differences.

  VOCALOID3 Editor  Tiny VOCALOID3 Editor
Editing and playback track number  16  1
The maximum number of bars  999  17
Effects  VST plug-ins available  With only the reverb
Job plugin features  Is  Without
V2 library import capabilities  Is  Without
Undo/Redo  No limit  One time only
Import functions  VSQX, VSQ, SMF, WAV WAV
WAV tracks  2-Track stereo and Mono Stereo

Unless you are ok with these limitations or already have a full vocaloid 3 editor I don't recommend buying this software. If you are ok with these limitations or already have a full vocaloid 3 editor then buying this software may be good deal for you.
